The accumulation of greenhouse gases (GHG) in the atmosphere, with carbon dioxide being the most significant contributor, is a major environmental problem as it impacts significantly on climate change. The development of new catalysts and chemical reactions that incorporate CO2 are needed to reduce its further emission significantly. Deep eutectic solvents (DES) have garnered increasing attention as environmentally friendly catalysts in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide (CO2) with epoxide substrates to produce cyclic carbonates. Their appeal stems from their facile synthesis, cost-effectiveness, low vapour pressure, and thermal stability. In this study, we present a convenient solvent-free synthesis method for nine deep eutectic solvents (DES), utilizing varying compositions of quaternary amine salts (N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium hydroxide, [TEA-12][OH]) and quinaldic acid [Q-COOH]. These deep eutectic solvents were thoroughly characterized using several techniques, including FTIR, NMR, DSC, and TGA. Moreover, their efficacy for the solvent-free fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates were evaluated. Among the tested compositions, [TEA-12]:[Q-COOH] (0.9:0.1) exhibited the lowest melting point (100.17 °C) and highest catalytic activity, showcasing an optimized Turn-Over Frequency (TOF) of 1466 h−1. This remarkable result represents a significant advancement in the application of DES for CO2 fixation, exceeding the previous highest catalytic activity observed with TBAB:Citric acid (2.5:1) by more than tenfold. Introduction Deep eutectic solvents (DES) are ionic compounds comprised of a hydrogen bond acceptor (HBA) and a hydrogen bond donor (HBD) [1–3]. These two interact through Van der Waals and hydrogen bond interactions, with the latter being the primary mode of interaction [4,5]. Due to surface ionic charges, DES are often called ionic liquids (IL) [5,6]. However, ionic liquids have one discrete cation or anion, whereas DES arise from the complexation of two charged molecules [1,7]. Typically, DES are divided into five categories [8–11]: (I) quaternary ammonium salt and metal halide, (II) quaternary salt and metal halide hydrate, (III) quaternary salt and hydrogen bond donor, (IV) metal halide and hydrogen bond donor, (V) non-ionic molecular hydrogen bond acceptor and a hydrogen bond donor [4]. A DES refers to a liquid where the molar ratio of two components yields the lowest melting point; thus, the obtained liquid is close to the eutectic composition of the mixture [3,8,9]. In this paper, we focus on type III DES where a quaternary ammonium salt is complexed with a hydrogen bond donor, quinaldic acid. The obtained DES has a lower melting point relative to each of its starting material, and this is due to charge delocalization taking place through hydrogen bonding occurring between the two moieties [9,12]. The general formula for a DES is given in Eq. (1) [1,10,11]: (1) ( HB A + ) ( X − ) n ( HBD ) Where HBA is a quaternary salt electron acceptor, X − is a Lewis base, usually a halide or a hydroxide. Complexation occurs between anionic X − and the hydrogen bond donor, and n represents the number of molecules of HBD that will complex with X −. DES have diverse applications, such as gas absorption [13], electrochemistry [14], nanotechnology [15,16], and can be solvents [17], extractions of metals [18], biological samples [2,3,19,20], and catalysis [21]. With an increase in energy demand due to a growing population, fossil fuels are burnt, resulting in increased levels of carbon dioxide emissions. Thus, there is a pressing demand for the development of chemical processes that can alleviate the issue of carbon dioxide emissions. Utilizing and converting CO2 into commercially valuable compounds can be used as an alleviation strategy. One of the most prevalent chemical reactions for CO2 utilization is the co-polymerization of epoxides and CO2 in the presence of a catalyst to yield carbonates and polycarbonates [22]. The carbon dioxide molecule is well-stabilized and needs energy and a catalyst for it to undergo any chemical changes. During the co-polymerization of carbon dioxide with an epoxide, a Lewis acid activates the epoxide by coordination, and a co-catalyst facilitates the nucleophilic opening of the epoxide [23–25]. Cyclic carbonates have many applications, such as electrolytes in lithium-ion batteries, aprotic polar solvents, fuel additives, and starting material for polycarbonates [23]. In recent years, DES have gained attention as potential green carbon dioxide capture and conversion alternatives [26–29]. Wu and co-workers investigated different reaction conditions with the cycloaddition of CO2 with propylene oxide using a choline chloride-based DES catalyst. Initially the product conversion was 32.9 % [30]. However, upon adding a potassium chloride co-catalyst the conversion was 87.8 %. In a separate study, Sheng and co-workers demonstrated an effective method for CO2 fixation into cyclic carbonates using imidazole-based DES [31]. They successfully converted a wide range of epoxides with various functional groups into cyclic carbonates with excellent yields without the need for additional solvents or additives. Type III DES lack metal centres, unlike their inorganic counterparts [32], which can frequently be toxic due to their inherent toxicity. DES are considered green alternatives to ionic liquid catalysts because they have low vapour pressures resulting in reduced emissions of pollutants [33], non-flammability [34], low cost, and low toxicity [35–37]. They also provide a homogeneous reaction medium that facilitates the dissolution of reactants for better reactivity. Additionally, it has the potential to stabilize intermediates. Due to their solubility, they act as both a reaction medium and catalyst [38] and this can potentially enhance yield and reaction rate for carbon dioxide conversion. Additionally, due to their tunability and unique properties DESs lead to lower energy requirements during carbon dioxide fixation. This research presents a series of novel type III DES catalyst that have a ten times higher efficiency for carbon dioxide fixation in comparison to the highest reported DES catalyst to date, even without the use of a co-catalyst. The catalysts were obtained via a solvent-free experimental procedure and were characterized by conventional methods and their catalytic activities are reported. Synthesis Materials and methods All reagents and solvents were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and Merck. These reagents were bought in high purity and were used without further purification. The synthesized products were characterized using the below techniques. Nuclear magnetic resonance (1H) spectra were recorded on a 400 MHz Bruker AVANCE III NMR spectrometer (operating at 25 °C) with a 5 mm BBI H-BB-D probe with z-gradients and the chemical shifts were reported relative to SiMe4 at 0.0 ppm. Attenuate Total Reflection Fourier-transform infrared (ATR FTIR) spectra were measured neat with a Bruker Tensor 27 IR spectrometer, fitted with a Pike miracle single bounce diamond ATR crystal, and analysed with OPUS v1.1 software. For thermal decomposition and melting point determination, ca. 5 mg of sample was heated with a heating rate of 10 °C/min. For Thermo-gravimetric analyses (TGA), the TGA 5000 Discovery Series instrument was used under a nitrogen atmosphere. The thermograms were analysed on the TRIOS v2.1.2.6 software. Melting point was determined by differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) and the analysis was performed on the DSC 2500 Discovery series. The data was also analysed on the TRIOS software. Catalytic testing was performed in a 25 cm3 Parr Reactor (2430HC, Parr Instrument Company) with 4848 Reactor Controller and Magnetic stirrer. Synthesis of ammonium salt A quaternary ammonium salt was synthesized by a solvent-free procedure amended from Atlaskina and co-workers [39]. To prepare N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide salt [TEA-12][Br], 1-bromododecane was reacted with triethylamine at 80 °C for 24 h under inert atmosphere with argon flow. To remove unreacted starting material, the crude product was washed three times with diethyl ether and the solvent was decanted. The obtained product (N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide ([TEA-12][Br]) was air dried and then vacuum dried overnight to yield 90.0 % pure [TEA-12][Br]. 1H NMR (300 Mz, DMSO‑d6 ) δH ppm: 8.17 (d, 4H), 8.04 (d, 4H). ATR FTIR ν(OH) 2300- 3300 cm−1, ν(CO) 1725 cm−1, ν(NN) 1470 cm−1 (See Fig. S1 in the Supporting document). Ion exchange of the Br− with OH− in the ammonium salt To obtain, the hydroxide ammonium salt used for the synthesis of the ionic catalysts, an anionic resin exchange reaction was carried out. However, prior to this exchange, the Amberlyst A21 resin was subjected to an activation process described by Atlaskina and co-workers [39]. An aqueous solution of N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium bromide was passed through a column packed with the activated resin containing hydroxyl groups to obtain N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium hydroxide ([TEA-12][OH]) in 90.0 % yield. 1H NMR: (400 MHz, chloroform-d1 , 25 °C) δ 0.87: (3H, t, CH), δ 1.24–1.39: (27H, m, CH), δ 1.67 (2H, s, CH), δ 3.19–3.23 (2H, m, CH), δ 3.47–3.50 (6H, dd, CH), δ 3.55 (1H, s, OH). ATR FTIR ν(OH) 3100- 3600 cm−1, ν(C-H) 2800- 2900 cm−1, ν(CO) 1600 cm−1. Preparation of ionic DES catalysts Nine ionic catalysts were prepared by mixing N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium hydroxide ([TEA-12][OH]) with quinoline-2-carboxylic acid [Q-COOH] at varying ratios. Preparation was conducted at 80 °C by mixing the two reagents without the addition of a solvent. The synthetic ratios (Table 1 ) and characterization data of the catalysts are given below: Catalytic test The catalytic CO2 fixation tests were conducted in a Parr-reactor (25 cm3) with a CO2 gas line, using an adopted procedure from literature (Scheme 1 ) [40]. Epichlorohydrin (5 cm3, 64 mmol, ECH) and DES catalyst (0.1 mol %) were loaded into the reactor, which was first flushed with 5 bar CO2 to remove all air from the reactor. Subsequently, the reactor was pressurised with 15 bar of CO2 and heated to 90 °C for 30 min. Afterward, the reactor was allowed to cool to room temperature, and any excess gas was released. The resulting liquid product was subjected to qualitative and quantitative analysis using 1H NMR. Each catalytic reaction was repeated twice to minimize experimental errors. The turnover frequency (TOF) was calculated from chloropropene carbonate yield per mole of DES catalyst used, as shown in SI Section 1.6. Results and discussion The physiochemical properties of DESs are influenced by the ratio of the two components (the hydrogen bond acceptor (HBA) and a hydrogen bond donor (HBD)). In this study the HBA is N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium hydroxide ([TEA-12][OH]) while the HBD is quinoline-2-carboxylic acid [Q-COOH]. Eleven different DESs were prepared by varying the ratio of the [TEA-12][OH] and [Q-COOH]. NMR The 1H NMR spectra of all eleven DESs exhibit similar peaks within the 0–8.5 ppm range (Fig. 1 A, SI). However, the relative intensities of these peaks varied depending on the synthesis ratio (see Fig. 1(A)). Among the DESs examined, ten distinct peaks are observed, with the exception of [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] ratios of 1.0:0.0 and 0.0:1.0 (the two pure compounds), which exhibit four and six peaks, respectively. All the other compounds consist of a mixture of the two ionic substances, which can be considered as separate starting materials. Fig. 1(B) shows the obtained DESs' general structure and will be used as a reference image for proton integration. The first resonance at ∼0.8 ppm integrates for three protons and it corresponds to the hydrogen atoms of the methyl group (-CH3), labelled C1. This is followed by a multiplet at ∼1.2 ppm, which integrates for 27 protons attributed to the alkyl protons (-CH2 and –CH3) from C2-C10, C13-C15. The subsequent three resonances at ∼1.7, ∼3.2 and ∼3.5 ppm integrate for 2, 2 and 6 protons, respectively. These correspond to the protons of C12 and C16-C18, respectively. These first four resonances (ranging from 0.8 to 3.5 ppm) are associated with the ammonium salt ([TEA-12][OH]), hence; they are absent in the spectrum for DES [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH](0.0:1.0), as it does not contain any ammonium salt. The remaining six resonances are associated with the carboxylic acid (HBA) and they are absent for [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] (1.0:0.0), as it does not contain any carboxylic acid. All the protons associated with the acid moiety integrate for one proton each. These resonances appear as six distinct peaks. The first two triplets at ∼7.7 and 7.8 ppm are associated with the protons of C25 and C26, respectively. The remaining four doublets at approximately 7.9, 8.2, 8.3, and 8.4 ppm correspond to the following carbon atoms: C24, C27, C21 and C22 respectively. The general trend is that upon addition of the acid to the ammonium salt and formation of the DES, there is a slight shift of the first four resonances to higher ppm values. Although it is worthy to note the shift is not significant (x < 0.1). ATR FTIR Figure S1 in the supporting information shows the ATR FTIR spectra for all the prepared DESs. These spectra are similar with the only difference being the difference of intensity of the peaks, which stems from the variation in composition of the two starting material during mixing. There are three primary absorption bands corresponding to the –OH, C-H and CO functional groups. The hydroxyl peak appears in the range of 3100- 3600 cm−1, while the alkyl band is observed between 2800- 2900 cm−1. These bands are attributed to the [TEA-12][OH] starting material and their intensities diminish as its concentration decreases in the DES composition. The carbonyl peak associated with [Q-COOH] is observed at 1600 cm−1. Conversely, the carbonyl peak associated with [Q-COOH] becomes prominent as its concentration in the DES composition increases. Thermal analysis The melting properties and thermal decomposition of the sample were determined as shown in Table 2 and in the supporting information (SI, Figs. S2–S11). The thermal decomposition of all 11 DESs occurs within a temperature range of 182 to 213 °C. DES 1 through 6, with varying ratios ranging from [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] 1.0:0.0 to 0.5:0.5, exhibit a two-step decomposition profile, while DES 7 through 11, with varying composition from [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] 0.4:0.6 to 0.0: 1.0, display a one-step decomposition profile. From the above, there is a discernible trend; as the concentration percentage of [TEA-12][OH] decreases below 50 %, the ionic catalysts' decomposition proceeds in a single step. This initial decomposition step is likely attributable to the detachment of the hydroxide anion (OH−). Thus, when the concentration of [TEA-12][OH] is low, the presence of the hyudroxide anion is so minimal that it remains undetectable during thermal decomposition analysis. The DSC profile of all the DES showed an endothermic melting point, ranging between 116 and 157 °C. (SI, Figs. S12–22) All the DES have a lower melting point than the individual starting materials as shown in Fig. 2 . Hence, they are classified as deep eutectic solvents. [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] (0.9: 0.1) has the lowest melting point observed at 100.17 °C. CO2 utilization via cycloaddition reaction The catalytic performance (see Fig. 3 and SI, Fig S22 for the % conversion, selectivity and TOF) of all the DES was assessed for the solvent-free CO2-epichlorohydrin (ECH) cycloaddition reaction. Among the different formulations, [Q-COOH] exhibited the lowest activity, yielding only a 2 % conversion rate with a turnover frequency (TOF) of 22 h−1 and 67 % selectivity. However, a notable enhancement in catalytic activity was observed upon increasing the proportion of [TEA-12][OH] in the mixture. In particular, a ratio of 0.9: 0.1 ([TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH]), yielded the highest catalytic activity, achieving a 66 % conversion with a TOF of 649 h−1. This represents a 5.4 % increase compared to the reaction catalysed with only [TEA-12][OH]. Both [TEA-12][OH] and the nine ionic DES solutions exhibited similar selectivity of ∼95 %. Optimisation of catalytic conditions The catalytic efficiency of the high-performing 0.9: 0.1 ([TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH]) mixture was further improved through systematic exploration of various factors, including initial CO2 pressure, catalyst quantity, reaction duration, and temperature (Table 3 , Fig. 5 and SI, Figs. S23–S26). Increasing the CO2 pressure up to 17 bar resulted in a progressive increase in conversion and turnover frequency (TOF), culminating in a peak TOF of 678 h−1. However, a further increase in CO2 pressure led to a decline in catalytic activity (Table 3 entry 1–5 and Fig. 4 A). This initial increase in catalytic activity can be attributed to the heightened concentration of CO2 within the liquid phase, fostering more effective interaction between CO2 and the substrate. Conversely, the decrease in activity beyond the 17 bar threshold can be explained by catalyst inhibition due to excess CO2 [41,42]. Elevating the reaction temperature increased conversion but decreased selectivity due to the formation of dimers and diols (Table 3 entry 6–10 and Fig. 4B) [43]. The highest selectivity-normalized TOF was achieved at 130 °C. While a maximum conversion of 87 % was attained at 150 °C, the TOF significantly dropped due to reduced selectivity at high temperatures. Prolonging the reaction time led to increased conversion while maintaining a selectivity of 87 % (Table 3 entry 11–15 and Fig. 4C), but the TOF decreased from 1466 to 152 h−1. An increase in the amount of catalyst led to higher conversion of ECH-CO2 to chloropropylene carbonate, peaking at 93 % with a 0.4 mol% catalyst loading (Table 3 entry 16–18 and Fig. 4D). However, the maximum TOF of 1466 h−1 was achieved with the lowest catalyst amount (0.1 mol%), as TOF exhibited an inverse relationship with the catalyst quantity. In summary, the optimal reaction conditions for enhancing TOF and selectivity in the ECH-CO2 cycloaddition reaction using the 0.9: 0.1 ([TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH]) catalyst were determined to be an initial CO2 pressure of 17 bar, a catalyst loading of 0.1 mol%, a temperature of 130 °C, and a reaction time of 30 min (Entry 11, Table 3). Catalytic activity of [TEA-12]:[Q-COOH] (0.9: 0.1) for cycloaddition of CO2 by selected epoxide substrates The versatility of the 0.9: 0.1 ([TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH]) mixture was evaluated by applying the optimized reaction conditions to the conversion of various epoxide substrates (Table 4 ). Exceptional conversions were observed for terminal epoxides with electron-withdrawing function groups (ECH), while epoxides with electron-donating functional groups (propylene oxide and 1,2-epoxybutane) showed lower activity. This is possibly attributed to the favouring of the nucleophilic attack on the ECH ring by the catalyst [44]. The (+)-limonene-1,2-epoxide with internal epoxide displayed limited catalytic activity due to the hindrance caused by the bulky 6-membered ring and substituents present in the epoxide molecule [45]. Comparison with other DES catalysts The DES catalyst that previously held the record for epoxide-CO2 cycloaddition reaction is the TBAB:citric acid combination in a 2.5: 1 ratio [29]. This DES achieved an impressive 95 % conversion and 102 h−1 TOF for PrO-CO2 cycloaddition (see Table 5 for comparison of cycloaddition catalysis of CO2 with ECH using DES). This was attributed to the synergic effect between –Brˉ and –OH groups in accelerating the ring opening of the epoxide [46]. In contrast, the high performing [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] (0.9: 0.1) mixture surpasses this TOF by 180 % at low temperature (70 °C) and over 14 times at optimized reaction temperature of 130 °C. However, the [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] (0.9: 0.1) catalyst was not reuseable Catalytic mechanism Various experimental and DFT calculation have shown that the presence of Lewis base (LB) and Lewis acid (LA) sites is responsible for the catalytic activity of DES in CO2-epoxide cycloaddition [29]. Fig. 5 shows a plausible mechanism for [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] catalysed CO2-epoxide cycloaddition reaction. The epoxide ring is opened by H-bond formation between the O of the epoxide and the N of [TEA-12][OH] as well as nucleophilic attack by OH− resulting in an oxy-anion intermediate [52]. CO2 can be activated through two routes: attack from the N of quaternary ammonium centre and that of the [Q-COOH]. The activated epoxide intermediate then reacts with CO2 to yield the cyclic carbonate product. In summary, the high catalytic activity of [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] (0.9:0.1) can be attributed to the LA and LB sites of the N centre of [TEA-12][OH] as well as an additional enhancement of the LA sites by [Q-COOH]. Conclusion A series of deep eutectic solvents (DESs) catalysts composed of [TEA-12][OH] and [Q-COOH] with varying ratios were prepared in a solvent-free procedure. These DESs were thoroughly characterized using NMR, ATR FTIR, DSC, and TGA techniques, confirming their composition and thermal properties. These compounds are considered as deep eutectic solvents, because all the obtained mixtures have a lower melting point than the individual starting material. The DESs exhibited high thermal stability, making them suitable for high-temperature catalytic reactions. The DES with the lowest melting point of 100.17 °C was [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] with a ratio of 0.9:0.1. The catalytic activity of the DESs for the fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates was evaluated, and the 0.9:0.1 ratio of [TEA-12][OH]:[Q-COOH] emerged as the most efficient catalyst, with a TOF of 1466 h−1 at optimized reaction conditions. This results surpass the previously reported highest catalytic activity by a DES by more than tenfold and this represents a significant advancement in the application of DESs for CO2 fixation. Overall, this study demonstrates the potential of DESs as green and efficient catalysts for CO2 conversion, offering a promising avenue for the development of sustainable processes for carbon dioxide utilization and reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. coredata.dc:description: The accumulation of greenhouse gases (GHG) in the atmosphere, with carbon dioxide being the most significant contributor, is a major environmental problem as it impacts significantly on climate change. The development of new catalysts and chemical reactions that incorporate CO2 are needed to reduce its further emission significantly. Deep eutectic solvents (DES) have garnered increasing attention as environmentally friendly catalysts in the cycloaddition of carbon dioxide (CO2) with epoxide substrates to produce cyclic carbonates. Their appeal stems from their facile synthesis, cost-effectiveness, low vapour pressure, and thermal stability. In this study, we present a convenient solvent-free synthesis method for nine deep eutectic solvents (DES), utilizing varying compositions of quaternary amine salts (N,N,N-triethyldodecan-1-aminium hydroxide, [TEA-12][OH]) and quinaldic acid [Q-COOH]. These deep eutectic solvents were thoroughly characterized using several techniques, including FTIR, NMR, DSC, and TGA. Moreover, their efficacy for the solvent-free fixation of CO2 to cyclic carbonates were evaluated. Among the tested compositions, [TEA-12]:[Q-COOH] (0.9:0.1) exhibited the lowest melting point (100.17 °C) and highest catalytic activity, showcasing an optimized Turn-Over Frequency (TOF) of 1466 h−1. This remarkable result represents a significant advancement in the application of DES for CO2 fixation, exceeding the previous highest catalytic activity observed with TBAB:Citric acid (2.5:1) by more than tenfold.
coredata.dc:title: Highly efficient DES-based catalytic systems for carbon dioxide utilization via cycloaddition with epoxide substrates
